knimeNode.name: Numeric Outliers
knimeNode.shortDescription: Detects and handles outliers for all numerical columns.

intro.p: This node detects and treats the outliers for each of the selected columns individually by means of interquartile range (IQR).

To detect the outliers for a given column, the first and third quartile (Q1, Q3) is computed. An observation is flagged an outlier if it lies outside the range R = [Q1 - k(IQR), Q3 + k(IQR)] with IQR = Q3 - Q1 and k >= 0. Setting k = 1.5 the smallest value in R corresponds, typically, to the lower end of a boxplot's whisker and largest value to its upper end.
Providing grouping information allows to further detect outliers only within their respective groups. Columns for which outliers have to be detected will be skipped when computing the groups.
If an observation is flagged an outlier, one can either remove the whole row from the data or replace it by some other value.
Missing values contained in the data will be ignored, i.e., they will neither be used for the outlier computation nor will they be flagged as an outlier.

tab.name: Outlier Selection (Outlier Settings)
tab.option: Allows the selection of columns for which outliers have to be detected and treated. If "Compute outlier statistics on groups" (see tab "Group Settings") is selected, the outliers for each of the columns are computed solely with respect to the different groups.

tab.name: General Settings (Outlier Settings)
tab.option: Allows to scale the interquartile range (IQR). The default is k = 1.5.
If checked the domain of the selected outlier columns is updated.

option.name: Use heuristic for quartile calculation (memory friendly)

tab.option:
If use heuristic is selected the quartiles will be calculated using a different approach than otherwise. While this heuristic is strongly favorable for large data sets due to its lower memory requirements while being rather precise, its results can be pretty far away from the accurate results for smaller data.
Consequently, we recommend to check this option only if the data set is large enough, or memory is an issue.

Typically the value of the quartiles is not part of the input, but lies between two observations. The estimation type allows to specify how to deal with this problem, e.g., R_4 applies linear-interpolation. A detailed explanation of the different options can be found here
Note this option is only available if the use heuristic option is not selected.

tab.name: Outlier Treatment (Outlier Settings)
tab.option:
Defines three different strategies to treat outliers:
Replace outlier values: Allows to replace outliers based on the selected "Replacement strategy"
Remove outlier rows: Removes all rows from the input data that contain in any of the selected columns at least one outlier
Exclusively retain outlier rows: Retains only those rows of the input data that contain at least one outlier in any of the selected columns

Allows to apply the selected treatment strategy to
All outliers
Outliers below lower bound
Outliers above upper bound

Defines two different strategies to replace outliers:
Missing values: Replaces every outlier by a missing value
Closest permitted value: Replaces the value of each outlier by the closest value within the permitted interval R. If the column type is an integer the replacement value is the closest integer within the permitted interval.
Note that this option is only enabled if outliers have to be replaced.

tab.name: Group Selection (Group Settings)
tab.option: If selected, allows the selection of columns to identify groups. A group comprises all rows of the input exhibiting the same values in every single column (similar to the GroupBy node). The outliers will finally be computed with respect to each of the individual groups.

Move the columns defining the groups into the Include list. The group definition will take priority, i.e. if a column is selected for both group definition and outlier handling, it will be used to define groups (no outlier handling done for that column).

tab.name: Memory Policy (Group Settings)
tab.option: Processes the groups in the memory. This option comes with higher memory requirements, but is faster since the table does not need any additional treatment.

ports.inPort: Numeric input data to evaluate + optional group information
ports.outPort: Data table where outliers were either replaced, rows containing outliers were removed, or exclusively retained
Data table holding the number of members, i.e., non-missing values and outliers as well as the lower and upper bound for each outlier group
Model holding the permitted interval bounds for each outlier group and the outlier treatment specifications
